The way this is being experimented with is that a heart is stripped of donor-cells and host stem cells are implanted into the structure, forced to differentiate with growth factor and a semi-artificial "host" heart is grown as a donor. After being cultured to maturation you'd implant it and give the host a combination of antibiotics and immunosuppressants because there's still a risk of opportunistic infection and graft rejection even with host tissue. It's incredibly difficult to culture an entire tissue like this and the techniques for manipulating stem cells with growth factors aren't really advanced enough for us to grow a true replica.   It has been done with more simple tissues though and is probably the best bet we have.

Were able to transport it that far beacuse we have self pulled wagons, that can go magnitudes faster and further than a horse (and cheaper for most people). We were able to close down roads (that connect most of the planet together) well before they got there, by communicating over that distance indistinguishable from instantly. Yes, a small portion of donor DNA was found in these swabs. These are crime labs, they are not sitting there and sorting specific cell lines out, they are just swabbing and running everything they collect. Within those cheek swabs are white blood cells, that is what they are picking up on.  Now if you want to get super technical, I believe there are some studies that have shown tumor DNA making their way into other cell lines, so it's possible there is some donor DNA in the epithelial cells themselves, but it's not making new sperm that this man could have a child that is genetically the donors.

As someone who had a kidney transplant as well here is a little advice if it happens to you. It's extremely common to have rejection a month or two after the transplant. When I went in it seemed like none of the doctors were that concerned but I realized after the fact it is so common and so easily treated it's not as big as a deal as you would expect. The shots they give you to fix it also make you feel a bit crazy for a day or two. Hopefully you don't get this but if you do they can handle it.

While you are correct, you have to remember that organ harvesting occurs before the patient dies, inside a really small window. If the patient's dying, the doctor has to weigh his estimation on saving him against the fact that if he tries in vain for too long, the organs will also be lost and thus he has to make a choice. And since every graduate of Medical Schools has to make the Hippocratic Oath which states that saving the patient is to be pursued at all costs, this "should I save his life or his organs?" dilemma creates a rather ugly situation.

They are already kind-of doing this with heart-lung machine, for instance for cardiac transplants. They chill the body to slow down metabolism and damage, chill the blood and stop the circulation, while they do their business. It's always a case of fighting the time, so less tissue damage can occur, but AFAIK people have perfectly recovered from procedures lasting an hour or so. Of course, reattaching a head will probably take much longer, hence the gamble - but this part is not science-fiction. The part where they reattach his spinal cord and nerves is though, nobody has ever done it before (besides last year's audacious attempt using nasal stem cells, which actually worked - but the guy had only partially severed spinal cord). But I guess even if they leave the guy quadriplegic, it would still be a great success.

Gunshot to the brainstem (as in gun in the mouth)  will take you out instantly, and not damage any transplantable organs.

Say they're bleeding to death from an accident, so heart, lung, liver, kidneys, cornea, blood, bone marrow can save lots of people. If that doctor now had had patients that needed all this, wouldn't it be the responsible thing to do to let the one person die and save the others? Sure, that's a philosophical question, because then you're getting into the territory where healthy people being killed to heal sick people starts making sense. I support the opt-out and wouldn't mind my body being harvested after death to save others, yet there are some things to consider that are way more complex than just "stupid retards that don't like this idea".

The case history is enough to show that her vaccination status wasn't the major factor and there were multiple contraindications to her receiving the transplant.  Heck, the previous rejection and infection would have made a double lung transplant extremely risky, and if there was another possible recipient, the math just makes sense.  Organs have a very limited shelf life, and most don't realize that there are "minor" and transitory factors that work into the decision of who gets an organ. Yes, a small portion of donor DNA was found in these swabs. it's likely because when you receive a transplant, you're already considered immunocompromised due to an orgna failing. but once you receive the new transplant organ, you'll be on immunosuppresant drugs for the remainder of your life.  they do this to dial back your immune system since it sees the new organ as foreign cells and your body will actually attack the new organ.  So not only were you ill enough to need a new organ, but now you're immunosuppressed from a. few. medications, and it puts you at real risk of severe complications. why risk losing a valuable transplant organ with a high risk individual that you aren't sure will take the process seriously when you can just give it to someone in equal need who has a statistically better chance at living an almost full life?

The trouble is, it isn't like insurance.  It's more like jury duty. You can be on a register of living donors but never actually be called up.  If you are called up,  there are plenty of legitimate reasons you can lie about to avoid going through with it. You can be on a register of postmortem donors.  You can be legitimately excluded from either or both.  If you are in a state to need an organ, you are likely to be. How long do you have to be on the donor register before you can get a new organ? How long can you be off the register and still get one? What happens if you fail to give your kidney or bone marrow when called upon?  How do you differentiate between legitimate and illegitimate refusal? What about congenital defects?

FYI, your information is a bit off. Hearts have about a 2-to-6-hour window of total ischemic time (time without blood flow). Livers are closer to 8 hours. Kidneys have about a 48-hour window. Additionally, the vast majority of recovered organs are kidneys, not hearts and lungs. Of course, in the kidney example, most of that time is cold ischemic time. Warm ischemic time limits are much shorter. If you restricted the time window to only apply to the organ recovery time (from cross-clamp to cold flush), then yes, there's only a short time window. But, since we have cold preservation, you can recover the kidneys and keep them on ice while you find one or more willing accepters.

No microscope, just a set of surgical tools. Usually we try to procure the cornea as quickly after death as possible. They can be recovered up to 24 hours after death if the body was cooled within 12 hours of death. It's pretty rare that we'd recover whole eyes and then later cut the corneas away for surgical use, but the sclera (the white part) can and absolutely is preserved for years to be used in procedures like glaucoma surgery.

I'll concede that, however unlikely, they may have found another hospital with such lax criteria that they may be willing to go through with the operation. The reason I find it extremely unlikely is because one of the biggest qualifiers looked for is what's known as "potentially injurious behavior."  If a patient cannot obey medical guidelines pre-operation, such as getting a vaccine, they're not going to give them an organ when there's a good chance they'll die one month later when they could give that organ to someone who's doing everything they can to survive. It's the same reason they don't give lungs to smokers and livers to alcoholics.

It's really not much different than reattaching an arm that got removed in an accident but it isn't common for multiple reasons. 1) The psychological aspect of having a piece of someone else's body so visibally a part of you. Scar tissue isn't going to vanish - it's basically collagen arranged in a specific way - it has no function and can block blood flow etc.   But I would assume it would be used when portions of the scarred liver are removed surgically and using this process to regrow healthy liver cells.   The liver does regrow naturally - but it's still a slow, limited process. It doesn't restore internal structure and could just be a useless chunk of a liver.   Controlling where it grows, replacing damaged areas and maintaining internal structure is likely the key here.   I can see multiple surgeries over a few years, gradually replacing damaged areas and allowing to heal until stable and healthy liver function is restored (may not need full liver restoration).

It really isn't in most cases. This been an internal ethical debate in most hospitals for at least a year and a half now. There are exceptions for temporary triage events (mass casualty usually.) In the US at least the official policy in most hospitals is "first come, first to receive all available resources." This is the legal and ethics department's "go-to" for reducing liability. It is not a way to save the most people, it is the cowards way out of having to make tough decisions. The headlines making this organ transplant rule "a thing" is precisely why hospitals will not use a true triage system except in extraordinary circumstances.

Let me introduce you to graft host disease. The normal problem with organ transplantation is that your immune system starts killing the new organ. Graft host disease is when your new immune systems starts attacking just about every part of your body. The worst part is that you still need to eat a lot of medicine. Those immune suppressing drugs are essential after any transplantation. Regular HIV medicine is a better choice as long as its a viable choice.

My sister has had 5 of these, and needs another one. They suck horribly. You start to wake up, and aren't fully there yet, and you can't breathe on your own because you are still on the ventilator. Everything is fuzzy but kind of aches.  As heart surgery patients go through recovery, they will cough a lot, which hurts like hell because your breastbone was broken and refused together. Cornea recipient here. I see many people here had this kind of surgery due to some condition, but I should warn everyone to be careful about contacts. Scar tissue isn't going to vanish - it's basically collagen arranged in a specific way - it has no function and can block blood flow etc.   But I would assume it would be used when portions of the scarred liver are removed surgically and using this process to regrow healthy liver cells.   The liver does regrow naturally - but it's still a slow, limited process. It doesn't restore internal structure and could just be a useless chunk of a liver.   Controlling where it grows, replacing damaged areas and maintaining internal structure is likely the key here.   I can see multiple surgeries over a few years, gradually replacing damaged areas and allowing to heal until stable and healthy liver function is restored (may not need full liver restoration).

The two causes of failure of a transplanted heart are rejection (your immuno-suppressants can't do their job anymore) or coronary graft dysfunction (in my exes case, the coronaries in his heart started to thicken for no good reason, resulting in poor blood flow). Doctors aren't yet sure why those are the two issues that result in failure. I know Stanford is conducting studies right now to see how to prevent issues like that from happening, or how to slow down the damage they cause.

Replacing the endothelium (cells on the back of the cornea) with an EK, as in DSAEK and DMEK, has become much more common in the last 10 years. Everyone used to get PKs (full-thickness corneal transplants) but the ability to do EKs has been a huge leap forward. There are cases where an EK would be inappropriate though, like stromal scar or keratoconus for example, where an EK would not be useful. EKs are good for many common diseases with endothelial dysfunction like pseudophakic bullous keratopathy or Fuchs corneal dystrophy.

It's one particular type of immunoglobulin (antibodies) that trigger an overreaction by the body. If I remember it right it's IgE (Immunoglobulin E) which is a specialised one, unlike the usual IgG and IgM that you're more likely to find in an immune response. They're meant to fight parasites, and part of their function is to activate basophils and mast cells, which then flood the area with histamines, interleukins, etc that then wreak absolute havoc when there's no real target there to deal with.

If you don't have the resources to distribute themselves, then it's no go. Period.   You have something like a 36 hour window to install a new organ, and ideally you do it in under 24 hours. And then sticking in the organ and managing the patient afterwards is far from simple. Surgery is never without risks. The decision to operate on a tumor requires an ongoing risk-benefit analysis which can change over time.  Some benign tumors can become malignant. During a colonoscopy, the doctor looks for benign adenomas that have a high risk of becoming malignant over time. Others (like the craniopharyngioma in the comment) have little to no risk of becoming malignant.

No microscope, just a set of surgical tools. Usually we try to procure the cornea as quickly after death as possible. They can be recovered up to 24 hours after death if the body was cooled within 12 hours of death. It's pretty rare that we'd recover whole eyes and then later cut the corneas away for surgical use, but the sclera (the white part) can and absolutely is preserved for years to be used in procedures like glaucoma surgery.

Yes, essentially a person who has a food allergy produces IgE antibodies when their B cells (produced in the bone marrow) interact with the food (antigen) causing acute inflammation. If you transfer the bone marrow, which has stem cells that can become many different cells, the immunity to that food is also transferred. It can work in the opposite direction as well and you can "vaccinate" against allergies by integrating b cells that produce IgG, which does not cause acute inflammation.

There isn't at present a treatment that you can either use or not use- the headline is pretty misleading (as per). What the researchers did was identify a specific population of cells with stem-like properties that could be a druggable target. It would be extremely difficult to isolate these cells in sufficient quantities to be useful clinically, and expanding them into useful numbers in a lab would also be difficult and certainly very expensive in the context of manufacturing a cost-effective drug. If someone published work saying "we found out that you can use this compound to stimulate liver regeneration" then you could ask "will this be used on patients" but at the moment that isn't the right question to be asking.

The main reason is that the immune response to infection can be highly variable. Some individuals have a robust response while others won't. Finally, requiring a covid vaccination (remember many others are already required) is a way to ensure that standards for transplant are easily followed rather than a complicated set of conditions.

The scar tissue we're talking about here is microscopic in nature and goes throughout the organ, destroying normal channels for flow of blood, lymph, bile, etc. Removing it surgically is impossible and yes, it will scar again if it was tried

Most of the scarring is homogenous. Even if there are areas that are worse removing them will not cause a liver to grow because you have to remove the scaffold that the cells grow into in the first place. The liver won't grow beyond its borders and there currently exists no technology to do that.

Transplants are not emergent procedures generally, there is a lot of prior workup and evaluation that gets done - this kid isn't even listed. It's not unusual for people (adult or pediatric) to be unable to be listed for both medical and social reasons, such as a lack of social support. Even though technically lifesaving in some senses, would be hard to make a case for temporary, emergency custody to do it, and even then, how do you ensure the follow through. Hearts aren't easy to come by. It's a sucky decision, but everytime  transplant committee decides a potential recipient may not be ideal, they are shunting that limited resource to someone who may be a better fit.

There's no wiggle room for bullshit as far as transplants go. Organs are one of the world's most valuable resources. If the healthcare team suspects you won't be meticulous with your health, won't treat the new organ with the care its value requires, they'll pass you over for someone who will.

It's not a bad question. All the bone marrow is replaced in a BMT. Sometimes, the doctors will transfuse the donor's bone marrow before the patient has theirs completely destroyed, leading to the patient having two immune systems. Eventually, though, the donor immune system will override the patients immune system, completing the transplant. The patient ceases to make their own blood cells after a transplant (unless the patient was also the donor, which often happens,) so the original white blood cells have no affect on the allergies.

Organ donation lies dear to my heart.  My dad has kidney disease, and (un)lucky for me, I got the genes that also create the disease.  My mom died several years ago from kidney cancer (dr.'s say it's not genetic).  When my dad went in to kidney failure we were fortunate to find that my sister was a match, so she donated her kidney.  It's been 8 years since then.  I am thankful every day that she was able and willing to do it, and that we still have one of our parents.  Unfortunately, for me, there might be a day when I will need a new kidney.   If you have the ability, please be willing to be a donor.  You can be a real life - life saver.

I suppose it depends if we are discussing a specific legal system, but there are definitely organ donation orders that are legal directives. In the US for example there is the "advanced health-care directive" which states the wishes of the patient if they should become incapacitated or deceased.  Possessions might be the wrong word, but you'd be hard pressed to find a western legal system that doesn't acknowledge the right to bodily autonomy, which organ donation is an extension of.

Lens is not in the mix here, the cornea is the clear rounded "dome" in the front of your eye, that's what got replaced.  I have keratoconus which causes that dome to malform, (should be smooth, mine basically has ripples), so I was seeing 6 of everything in that eye with large flares between the copies if whatever I was looking at was light.  Stitches were done by hand and the stitches are removed manually, (with a needle and then pulled), to relax the tension on the replacement cornea to get the replacement to form into a better, (hopefully right or correctable), shape by removing tension as they're taken out one at a time over the next year.  Takes about a year to be sorted and then we'll know what we have.

In my personal view, there should be no issue of consent here. I fail to see how there's a morally significant difference between a human corpse and human excrement - both are matter that was once incorporated in a sentient, sapient, emotional and rational being.  People place value on the corpse because it physically resembles that being, but this is an error. The fact that this happens cannot be ignored, and so we have to treat the corpse differently for instrumental moral reasons relating to the feelings of the deceased persons's family. But as for consent, a person has no right to control what happens to their corpse, because "their" corpse never actually belongs to them.  I think an opt-out consent system, as the world is now, is the necessary minimum concession for society to not reject the policy outright, but opting out is morally wrong.
That is quite worrying news for anyone who wishes to opt-out though. I foresee many an expensive lawsuit if they don't get an iron clad system sorted out, which they won't.

I don't remember which state did the experiment and I don't remember when they did it but, it wasn't all that long ago. In response to low enrollment in the US donor program, some researchers looked into ways of increasing enrollment. One of the things they found were that many of the applications at DMV simply hadn't been checked Yes or No. They were simply left blank meaning that it defaulted to No. They asked for permission to change the verbiage from opt-in to opt-out. What they found was that we aren't adverse to organ donation. We're adverse to making check marks. Now, why that wasn't adopted nationwide, I have no idea.

Pigs offer a number of unique advantages over other possible source animals. 1- ideal for mass production. A pig can reach proper size and weight for human transplants in less than a year, they have relatively large numbers of off springs per pregnancy, and the human infrastructure is already in place (like vets and animal techs).  Primates on the other hand take much longer to develop and likely their organs would be of insufficient size or ability to function. (See Dr. Keith Reemstma). 2- shared disease between pigs and humans do exist but are much less common than between humans and primates. There are a couple other reasons why pigs, but those are the main ones.

Ever see how things of different sized things like grains get sorted? They have a series of sieve like cloths. The grain gets bounced across the top and the bits small enough to go through do, and the larger bits bounce along a parallel path then get diverted off. There can be multiple layers of cloth to sort into smaller and smaller sizes but nothing ever stops, it just gets bounced to a new path.  I dare say this kidney would work on a similar principle,with the appropriate portions getting returned to the blood stream and the waste products being shunted to the bladder.

Ever see how things of different sized things like grains get sorted? They have a series of sieve like cloths. The grain gets bounced across the top and the bits small enough to go through do, and the larger bits bounce along a parallel path then get diverted off. There can be multiple layers of cloth to sort into smaller and smaller sizes but nothing ever stops, it just gets bounced to a new path.  I dare say this kidney would work on a similar principle,with the appropriate portions getting returned to the blood stream and the waste products being shunted to the bladder.

After death, the person is no more. All the legal power that he has resides in his will. A lot of things are assumed to be one way or the other to make things easier. This is a similar case, the person is not being interfered with, because he is no more. And now the accepted understanding is that the organs go to the public rather than in the ground. My father passed away from a heart attack. He was a smoker from around the age of 10 (or less) until 61 when he died. They wanted to use his lungs. The organ donor lady told us (because we were so surprised) that they are often more viable than people would expect and that smoker's lungs are often stronger than those of non-smokers. Then there was a complication and they were unable to use his lungs. The way it was described to us, it doesn't sound like it was because he was a smoker. They were able to use his eyes, though. So even though the sight he was able to pass on to someone else probably didn't save their life, at least it likely improved their life.
He actually was appalled how easy it was for him which is why he spent a lot of money before he died trying to create a true national organ donor registry.

Various different legal jurisdictions treat this differently. Under common law, the family is responsible for the disposal of the body, but not actually in ownership of it. It is part of the estate of the dead person (so your legal executors have the responsibility). Property enters probate which is a specific legal status reccognizing they are between owners.  A body in some legal jurisdictions is seen as the property of God regardless of whether you are alive or dead!

I'm actually doing my dissertation on the Welsh opt-out legislation. Deemed consent only goes ahead if you haven't specifically opted out. The heart is purely mechanical. It just pumps blood. Bone marrow is the source of nearly all types of a dozen or so blood cells. The bone marrow is responsible for a huge portion of our immune system by creating white blood cells, and it is responsible for creating platelet's progenitor cells which are responsible for blood clotting. Marrow is hugely more complicated with respect to human physiology than the heart, so I imagine this is not likely to be possible.

I'm actually doing my dissertation on the Welsh opt-out legislation. Deemed consent only goes ahead if you haven't specifically opted out.    Seriously, if you don't want your organs being donated, you need to opt-out when you have the option, talk about it with your family so they know, or appoint a representative who can say that you didn't want to donate your organs. The issues are completely different because there usually is enough blood donated for everyone. Under normal circumstances, nobody has to die because there was no blood available. There is no real issue with not enough blood. Unfortunately many people die each year because they could not get the transplant they are waiting for. There are not nearly enough organ donations for everyone who needs one.  So while it is nice that you and I donate blood, it doesn't make sense to have a "list" that prioritizes the blood if you need some - there is enough for everyone. But there are not enough organs for everyone - thus if you don't intend to donate your organs once you pass, it is perfectly fair that you get put on the list below everyone who is kind enough to do so.

Then in this case consent was given through explict body lauguage. Nothing was presumed. If the person starts to resist upon putting the canula in it is obvious they don't consent and any assumption of presumed consent would be false.  This is why the word "presumed consent" is an oxymoron.  The word presumed negates the word consent. With consent, a request is made and the individual is free to accept or decline the action voluntarily. With presumed consent, power over ANY action upon your body is automatically granted to the presumer, always requiring you to reclaim that power.  In many cases these actions are entirely ethical and necessary, but they are not consentual.

Unfortunately this technique would be unlikely to help. The main problems are that nerve transfers work within a certain window - after a certain amount of time, the end plates (where the nerve meets the muscle) die off, and the muscle becomes essentially irreversibly atrophied. Also, this technique relies on the availability of relatively close by, uninjured nerves that are expendable which can be used to supply input to the recipient nerves. In the case of spinal cord injury, especially in the lower limb, there are very few options available for donor nerves.

You'd end up with a pig that likely can't feed itself, and will lack many signs of illness, making it much harder (and expensive) to take care of. The gain is just an abstract sense that this is more moral, so the cost-benefit analysis just doesn't check out here.

It is part of the estate of the dead person (so your legal executors have the responsibility). Property enters probate which is a specific legal status reccognizing they are between owners.  A body in some legal jurisdictions is seen as the property of God regardless of whether you are alive or dead!

When I was a student, I attended a pre-transplant conference where a group of medical professionals and social workers review the recipient list to make sure they are ready. An organ is a precious and limited resource. Patients who are likely to waste an organ is definitely not a top priority. It has nothing to do with what the patient believes in.  They review alcohol use, medication adherence, support system, appointment adherence, etc. Vaccination status is also reviewed and what vaccines the patient will need to receive prior to transplant because complications from an infection can put strain on the organ and cause failure or death while on immunosuppressive drugs, which the patient has to take for the rest of their life to prevent the body from recognizing the new organ as foreign and attacking it.

This is already the case here in Wales, where I live, and there has been no public outcry. We have an opt-out system where the assumption is that everyone is happy to be on the organ-donor register. Anyone who wishes not to be on the register can apply to have their name removed. Furthermore their next of kin can refuse to allow their organs to be harvested after death if they so wish, even if they never themselves applied to be removed from the register.

Limbs can handle a lack of blood flow for a good while.  The rule of thumb for tourniquets is to try to get your limb to care within 3-4 hours to prevent serious harm.  6-8 hours is the cut-off point where most limbs won't make it. (pun intended)  Arms can handle being removed from blood supply for 30-120 minutes without any noticeable long-term harm.  For some surgeries it makes sense to temporarily stop blood flow to the limb until the surgery is over.  The lower arm is able to handle lack of blood for longer than the upper arm is.

This isn't really correct. For a lot of chains each kidney is taken out on the same day at the same time (early in the morning) but then the kidney can go almost anywhere in the US so long as it gets put back into someone that afternoon. I did an altruistic donation in Atlanta and my kidney flew (commercial) to New Jersey and went inside someone that afternoon. That recipients son had his operation to donate the same morning and his kidney went somewhere in California. And then there was another donation somewhere else. And then they actually split the chain up til the next week. So someone in the chain received a kidney a week before their donor continued the chain. The chain I kicked off was 6 kidneys long and from what I understand the process was pretty normal
An extremely rare case of this where a bunch of people participate is referred to as a domino surgery, thought that was neat

In the US, any contract involving organ donation is automatically unenforceable.   So hypothetically, person A could agree to donate his organ as part of a chain only if person B gets an organ.  If person B does their surgery and gets an organ, but person A hasn't donated yet, person A could back out, and under US law, it's perfectly legal, because you can't make binding contracts involving organ donation.

This isn't really correct. For a lot of chains each kidney is taken out on the same day at the same time (early in the morning) but then the kidney can go almost anywhere in the US so long as it gets put back into someone that afternoon. I did an altruistic donation in Atlanta and my kidney flew (commercial) to New Jersey and went inside someone that afternoon. That recipients son had his operation to donate the same morning and his kidney went somewhere in California. And then there was another donation somewhere else. And then they actually split the chain up til the next week. So someone in the chain received a kidney a week before their donor continued the chain. The chain I kicked off was 6 kidneys long and from what I understand the process was pretty normal

Even more interesting, there are organ transplant chains constructed where each person in need of an organ brings along someone who is willing to donate one (though not a match for themselves). Everyone registers in a database, and algorithm determines how to match the maximum number of people in long chain of transplants. This is also generally the most effective way to donate an organ altruistically - introducing a single kidney without any constraints allows the algorithm a lot more freedom, resulting in a lot more people getting transplants.

In the US, any contract involving organ donation is automatically unenforceable.   So hypothetically, person A could agree to donate his organ as part of a chain only if person B gets an organ.  If person B does their surgery and gets an organ, but person A hasn't donated yet, person A could back out, and under US law, it's perfectly legal, because you can't make binding contracts involving organ donation.

A lot of misinformation in this thread. Tylenol is a very safe medication unless you take too much. The general recommendation is not to exceed 4 grams in 24 hours. Tylenol typically comes in 325mg or 500mg so that is no more than 11 or 8 pills in 24 hours respectively. Most people do not need that much in a day, and if they do they should look into additional forms of pain management. NSAIDs (ibuprofen. Naproxen, aleve, Motrin etc.) are NOT safe for daily pain management. They should be taken in short courses, like 1-2 weeks at a time and then stopped. These medications will cause kidney problems, heart problems, and gastrointestinal bleeding if you take them for a prolonged period of time.

Skin donation, in most cases, is considered tissue donation. It is banked for future use in reconstructions or for burn victims. In these instances, it is recovered in very thin sheets. Face, limb, penis, and uterine transplants are called Vascularized Composite Allografts (VCA) and include skin, muscle, bone, nerves which together form a function unit.  Tissue recipients do not need to take anti-rejection medications, but a VCA recipient would.

In the US, any contract involving organ donation is automatically unenforceable.   So hypothetically, person A could agree to donate his organ as part of a chain only if person B gets an organ.  If person B does their surgery and gets an organ, but person A hasn't donated yet, person A could back out, and under US law, it's perfectly legal, because you can't make binding contracts involving organ donation.

That's how it works in Canada. If you have some one who wants to volunteer to be your donor, they get tested and then either you get their kidney, or you end up in an exchange like the above and cross trade between people. You are not allowed to solicit strangers for organs directly, the volunteer has to be someone you already know and have a relationship with. If someone wants to donate and is a "stranger" then they can still donate, but not directly to an individual. It would just go to the next person in the waiting list that matches, that doesn't have a volunteer donor of their own. The recipient also has to meet certain health criteria in order to receive any kidney, even if they have a willing donor, such as being within a certain BMI and maintaining good levels through dialysis.

The people who are on about backing out aren't entirely wrong, but the surgeries do not have to be completely simultaneous, just carefully coordinated. They usually need to do the removals at the same time to cover for consent or other issues, but the implants only start when the donor organs are nearing the hospital.

Limbs can handle a lack of blood flow for a good while.  The rule of thumb for tourniquets is to try to get your limb to care within 3-4 hours to prevent serious harm.  6-8 hours is the cut-off point where most limbs won't make it. (pun intended)  Arms can handle being removed from blood supply for 30-120 minutes without any noticeable long-term harm.  For some surgeries it makes sense to temporarily stop blood flow to the limb until the surgery is over.  The lower arm is able to handle lack of blood for longer than the upper arm is.

For a lot of chains each kidney is taken out on the same day at the same time (early in the morning) but then the kidney can go almost anywhere in the US so long as it gets put back into someone that afternoon. I did an altruistic donation in Atlanta and my kidney flew (commercial) to New Jersey and went inside someone that afternoon. That recipients son had his operation to donate the same morning and his kidney went somewhere in California. And then there was another donation somewhere else. And then they actually split the chain up til the next week. So someone in the chain received a kidney a week before their donor continued the chain. The chain I kicked off was 6 kidneys long and from what I understand the process was pretty normal

I understand your confusion. Organs can not be harvested from a dead person for many reasons. Primarily oxygen deprivation. If your heart isn't beating and you aren't breathing your organs "die", too. Organ donors are "alive" in that they are on machines that breath for them and keep their bodies oxygenated. But, they have no brain activity or they're so sick that they will die as soon as the machines are turned off. The organ donor is taken to surgery, in a real, sterile, surgical room, where they are still treated with dignity and respect. As soon as their usable organs are removed, the machines are turned off and the person dies. The organs then must be transplanted very quickly or they will be unusable. I hope I was able to clear it up for you.

"Opt-in" - people have to specifically say they want to donate organs (usually on their drivers license or advanced directive). "Opt-out" - people have to specifically say they DON'T want to donate. Many more organs will be donated under an opt-out system, because people are too lazy to fill out extra paperwork, or they just didn't care enough about the issue.

They aren't worthless they are just more likely to die after a transplant. Organ transplant requires a very stable routine of drugs, a requirement for a clean environment, dietary requirements. The incentive is to save a life for reduced time, something that already exists.

For a lot of chains each kidney is taken out on the same day at the same time (early in the morning) but then the kidney can go almost anywhere in the US so long as it gets put back into someone that afternoon. I did an altruistic donation in Atlanta and my kidney flew (commercial) to New Jersey and went inside someone that afternoon. That recipients son had his operation to donate the same morning and his kidney went somewhere in California. And then there was another donation somewhere else. And then they actually split the chain up til the next week. So someone in the chain received a kidney a week before their donor continued the chain. The chain I kicked off was 6 kidneys long and from what I understand the process was pretty normal

The experiment done in the 70's was not one that attempted to reconnect the spinal cord from the patient to the host body. This is arguably the biggest challenge for a surgery that would try to attemp this. Millions and millions of neural tissue would have to reconnect. Millioms of neurons would have to form new connections with a completely new body. The article mentions that neurons are more likely to form scar tissue when severed, not reconnect with a new body.  We do not have any evidence to suggest that one can connect the spinal cord of one person to the truncated cord of another.  Even considering the medical advancements made in the last four decades, it's still not enough to conclusively suggest that such a surgery is even possible

Anyone is eligible for a donation from their direct family. If your family wants to give you a liver then that really isn't an ethical issue, alcoholism or no. However for anonymous donations they need to prioritise the people who have the best chances of living. So things like being an alcoholic or having a recent suicide attempt or even not having high enough chances for survival percentage may disqualify you from getting donated tissue. If you are an alcoholic that ruined your liver then the chances are very high that you'll do so again. Some of the tests are done on samples from a large number of donors mixed together. It's much cheaper than testing each individual donation. As a result, if such a test comes back positive the options are to either test all the donations that were sampled for it individually (potentially prohibitively expensive), or throw them all out.

In my experience, there are few things harder than keeping a dead person "alive". All of the brain dead folks that are in the ICU awaiting organ donation are like a roller coaster. Because there is no autonomic input from the brain their blood pressures tank, then skyrocket, then tank again. Also, their electrolytes swing and you are playing catchup all the time to keep those organs perfused and viable for transplantation. The same thing will probably happen to this head transplant body. If you don't get brain input to the heart, diaphagm, and appropriate control of so many other things, this body will become just a vegetable that requires loads of machines to stay alive.

Everything is flipped left to right, like a mirror image. The organs are flipped too, so when you go to insert them, they won't connect correctly because they are flipped. Some organs like kidneys don't matter because those get tossed into the center of the abdomen and hooked up to the femoral artery, but the heart absolutely can't be flipped left to right.  A full liver transplant cannot be done with a flipped liver, but the partial might be able to do it. But that would be very tricky getting it inserted properly, and would have higher risk for complications.
